questions.answer: Selflessness

questions.question: What emotion does the poem mainly express?
questions.answer: Compassion

questions.question: Why does the poet mention the youth’s fair hair?
questions.answer: To symbolise innocence and inexperience

questions.question: What lesson does the poem teach us?
questions.answer: Help others without expecting anything

questions.question: Why does the poet choose an old pilgrim as the main character?
questions.answer: The poet uses an old pilgrim to show wisdom gained through life experience. His actions come from maturity and kindness. This makes his sacrifice more meaningful.

questions.question: What does the pilgrim’s silence while working show about his nature?
questions.answer: His silence shows humility and dedication. He does not seek praise or recognition. He only wants to help others.

questions.question: How does the setting of evening add depth to the poem?
questions.answer: Evening symbolises the end of the pilgrim’s life journey. It shows that he is near his final stage. Still he chooses to help others.

questions.question: Why is the chasm compared to a life obstacle?
questions.answer: The chasm is deep and dangerous. It represents the problems people face in life. Not everyone can cross such difficulties easily.

questions.question: What makes the bridge an act of kindness?
questions.answer: The old man builds the bridge without any benefit for himself. He does it only for future travellers. This makes it a selfless act.

questions.question: How does the poem define true service?
questions.answer: True service is helping others without expecting rewards. The pilgrim does not wait for thanks. He simply serves humanity.

questions.question: What does the pilgrim’s action teach about old age?
questions.answer: Old age does not mean weakness. It can be a time of wisdom and compassion. The pilgrim proves this through his action.

questions.question: Why is the fellow pilgrim confused by the old man’s act?
questions.answer: The fellow pilgrim thinks practically. He cannot understand selfless service. He measures actions by personal benefit.

questions.question: How is the fair-haired youth different from the old pilgrim?
questions.answer: The youth is inexperienced and unaware of dangers. The old pilgrim is wise and thoughtful. Their contrast shows generational difference.

questions.question: Why does the old man think about the youth’s future?
questions.answer: The old man understands that life is uncertain. He wants to make the path easier for others. This shows his caring heart.

questions.question: What does the pilgrim’s journey represent?
questions.answer: The journey represents the path of life. Every person must cross challenges. How we help others on the way defines our character.

questions.question: How does the poem describe compassion?
questions.answer: Compassion is shown through action, not words. The old man silently builds the bridge. His deeds express kindness.

questions.question: Why is the bridge built at the end of the pilgrim’s journey?
questions.answer: The pilgrim builds it when he no longer needs it. This highlights his selflessness. He works only for others.

questions.question: What is the moral lesson of the poem?
questions.answer: The poem teaches us to help others without expecting anything. It shows that kindness is true greatness.

questions.question: How does the poet show respect for elders?
questions.answer: The poet presents the old man as wise and caring. His actions guide the young. This shows respect for elders.

questions.question: Why is the chasm described as ‘cold and gray’?
questions.answer: These words create a feeling of danger and loneliness. They highlight the difficulty of crossing it. The mood becomes serious.

questions.question: How does the poem show responsibility towards society?
questions.answer: The pilgrim takes responsibility for people he may never meet. He prepares the path for them. This shows social duty.

questions.question: What does the old man expect in return for building the bridge?
questions.answer: The old man expects nothing. His happiness lies in helping others. This shows his pure intention.

questions.question: How does the poem encourage readers to act?
questions.answer: The poem inspires readers to help others in real life. It teaches kindness through example. It motivates moral action.

questions.question: Why is the pilgrim called a hero?
questions.answer: He does not fight wars or win battles. Yet his kindness saves lives. This makes him a true hero.

questions.question: How does the pilgrim’s tiredness make his action more meaningful?
questions.answer: The pilgrim is old and tired after his journey. Still he builds the bridge for others. This shows great sacrifice and dedication.

questions.question: What does the pilgrim’s work teach about true generosity?
questions.answer: True generosity means giving without expecting anything back. The pilgrim does not even meet the person he helps. This makes his kindness pure.

questions.question: Why is the pilgrim not worried about his own future?
questions.answer: The pilgrim knows his journey is almost over. He is more concerned about others who will come after him. This shows his selfless heart.

questions.question: How does the poem show the importance of thinking ahead?
questions.answer: The pilgrim imagines the problems future travellers may face. He prepares a safe path for them. This teaches us to think beyond ourselves.

questions.question: What role does imagination play in the poem?
questions.answer: The pilgrim imagines a young traveller in danger. This imagination guides his action. It shows that caring thoughts lead to good deeds.

questions.question: Why does the poet describe the chasm in detail?
questions.answer: The poet wants us to feel the danger of the chasm. This helps us understand why the bridge is necessary. It builds the seriousness of the scene.

questions.question: How does the poem show silent leadership?
questions.answer: The pilgrim does not command anyone. He leads by example through his action. This teaches silent leadership.

questions.question: What makes the pilgrim different from the fellow traveller?
questions.answer: The fellow traveller thinks only practically. The pilgrim thinks emotionally and morally. This difference highlights compassion.

questions.question: Why does the poet call the bridge a protection for youth?
questions.answer: Young people may not notice danger easily. The bridge saves them from falling. It protects them from mistakes.

questions.question: What does the pilgrim’s action say about true success?
questions.answer: True success is not wealth or fame. It is helping others sincerely. The pilgrim proves this through his deed.

questions.question: How does the poem inspire responsibility in readers?
questions.answer: The poem shows that our actions affect others. It encourages us to make life easier for people who follow us. This builds responsibility.

questions.question: What lesson does the pilgrim give about age and wisdom?
questions.answer: Age brings understanding and compassion. The pilgrim uses his wisdom for others. This shows the power of experience.

questions.question: Why is the pilgrim’s work more valuable than words?
questions.answer: He does not give speeches or advice. He works silently to help others. His actions speak louder than words.

questions.question: What message does the poem give about leaving a legacy?
questions.answer: We should leave behind goodness for others. The bridge is the pilgrim’s legacy. It lives even after he is gone.

questions.question: How does the poem show the beauty of unseen service?
questions.answer: The pilgrim may never meet the youth he helps. Still his service saves lives. This shows beauty in unseen kindness.

questions.question: Why is the pilgrim not offended by the fellow traveller’s doubt?
questions.answer: The pilgrim is calm and understanding. He does not argue or feel angry. His patience reflects maturity.

questions.question: What does the poem suggest about thinking beyond one’s lifetime?
questions.answer: The pilgrim thinks about people he will never meet. This teaches us to think beyond our own life. It is true selflessness.

questions.question: How is the pilgrim’s bridge a gift to the future?
questions.answer: The bridge will help travellers long after he is gone. It becomes a gift for generations. This shows lasting kindness.

questions.question: Why is the pilgrim’s work described as noble?
questions.answer: His work is done without any selfish motive. It benefits unknown people. This makes it noble.

questions.question: How does the poem teach the value of moral duty?
questions.answer: The pilgrim feels it is his duty to help others. He fulfils this duty quietly. This teaches moral responsibility.
